Topic.Title: Speculation of Monday's DELL opening price due to new bids?

Message.Msg: “What shareholders are telling you is that the floor is not $13.65,” Louis Meyer, a special situations analyst with Oscar Gruss & Son Inc., said in a phone interview. “Just based on the reputation of Blackstone, people are saying ‘I’m willing to give it the benefit of the doubt. My floor is now $14.25.’” For Blackstone and Icahn, a leveraged recapitalization offers a cheaper alternative to a full takeover, according to James Hill, who runs the private-equity practice at law firm Benesch, Friedlander, Coplan & Aronoff LLP. It’s also a “hybrid of necessity” that can help win shareholders’ approval, he said in a phone interview from Cleveland.

Topic.Title: What will happen to alien ware if Dell gets bought out?

Message.Msg: Dell could sell off the unit. I think it depends on who buys the company. As for Alienware being "dead," its client base is made up (mostly) of hardcore gamers. IMO only, those people still need to utilize desktops or high end laptops to play many of their video games (at least on the best settings).

Message.Title: DELL price drifting lower
Message.Msg: As the hype from the cavalier fake "offers' from Ichan, Blackstone etc... dies down, i expect that in the days and weeks prior to the vote, DELL stock price will find a home at or near the current $13.65 cash offer. Shareowners should decide whether they want $13.65 cash or have the stock trade down to the pre buyout $10.to $10.50 range. Looking out to 2015 and beyond, if DELL remains public, the stock price could become a $5 stock, or it could trade back up to $20. So much is dependent on the economy, market conditions, management ability to transform the company etc.... Good luck to all and hope this helps.

Message.Title: reality of the situation
Message.Msg: Mike Dell's $13.65 icash offer s a very generous, premium valuation. As the weeks pass by the reality of the situation becomes clear. that is, Dell is a struggling company trying to transform its business lines to higher margin, potential growth generating products and services. There is no guarantee the future initiatives will be succesful, so Mike dell and his LBO team are taking a significant risk by paying a premium to privatize the company. There are several institutional stockholders such as Southeastern Asset Management, who paid too much for their DELL shares, and owned them too many years. this has nothing to do with Dell's business operations , but it does reveal the ineptiitude of Southeastern's money managers. T Rowe Price is another DELL shareowner which paid too much and have no one to blame but their own money managers. The recent speculators, such as carl ichan and a bunch of amateur stock buyers, took a risk overpaying for their shares, but Dell is not responsible for their reckless, cavalier buying habits. When all the ridiulous hype and posturing recedes, and the dust settles, serious DELL investors will vote to decide whether to approve the 413.65 offer, or take their chances with DELL remaining a public company. Hope this helps.
Not going to happen, joint bid coming at 14.50 to go private
No it really does not help...................if you think $13.65 is a good price you must be ecstatic at the current price of $14.38 ???

Topic.Title: If I buy tomorrow, do I still get the 8 cents dividend

Message.Msg: No, you would need to buy at least 1 day before the ex-date . . . The ex-dividend date is two business days prior to the record date. To be a stockholder on the record date an investor must purchase the stock before the ex-dividend date. The latest date you can buy the stock to be a stockholder on record, and be entitled to the dividend, would be one day prior to the ex-dividend date to allow for the three stock trading day settlement of the purchase. If the investor purchases the stock the day before the ex-dividend date the investor would be a stockholder on the record date and would be entitled to receive the dividend payment.

Message.Title: What is so generous about 10x earnings?
Message.Msg: Take out the $9.00/share cash and the company is being valued at $4.65? or 3.4x earnings? 16x $1.35 is $21.60. 10x $1.35 is $13.50. Add the cash back and you get $22.50. I think at 10x earnings the company should approach $20. Am I missing something?
